recentPerformance.hitRate: Magic 2-1 without Paolo Banchero, Franz Wagner stepping up
recentPerformance.recentForm: Franz Wagner averaging 27.3 PPG in Banchero's absence
recentPerformance.cushion: Got +3.5 vs consensus +3, gaining extra half-point cushion

keyFactors.title: Warriors Road Struggles
keyFactors.description: Golden State 2-6 on road this season (25% win rate). Historically poor road defensive rating (117-130 DRTG). Warriors can't defend away from Chase Center - consistently allow 120+ points on road.

keyFactors.title: Magic Thriving Without Banchero
keyFactors.description: Orlando 2-1 without Paolo Banchero (shoulder). Franz Wagner elevated game to All-Star level, averaging 27.3 PPG. Balanced scoring with Wagner, Black, Carter creating matchup problems for Warriors.

keyFactors.title: Warriors Missing Jonathan Kuminga
keyFactors.description: Kuminga OUT with bilateral knee issues, creating frontcourt depth crisis. Magic's size advantage (Carter 6'10", Wendell 6'10") would dominate paint without Kuminga's rim protection.

keyFactors.title: Magic Elite Home Defense
keyFactors.description: Orlando 106.3 DRTG at home (3rd in NBA). Kia Center fortress where Magic control tempo. Expected Magic to suffocate Curry and force Warriors into difficult shots.

riskFactors: Stephen Curry capable of nuclear performances (career 62 points at this venue)
Warriors small-ball lineup can create tempo issues when hot from three
Magic young team prone to defensive lapses in close games
If Warriors shoot 40%+ from three, could steal road win

anthonyBlack.impact: Explosive off bench, game-high from reserves

stephenCurry.impact: Curry tried to carry Warriors but lacked support

quarterBreakdown.description: High-scoring start. Magic came out aggressive, Franz Wagner and Carter dominated paint early. Curry kept Warriors close with 11 first-quarter points.
Warriors responded in Q2, Curry heating up. Back-and-forth battle. Halftime: Magic 62, Warriors 59 - Magic leading within +3.5 spread comfortably.
Magic took control in Q3. Anthony Black explosive off bench with 13 third-quarter points. Defense locked in, held Warriors to 26. After three: Magic 93, Warriors 85 (+8 Orlando).
Both teams matched in Q4. Magic maintained lead throughout, Warriors couldn't make final push. Final: Magic 121, Warriors 113 - blowout outright win.

gameResults.whenCleared: Magic covered +3.5 spread from opening tip and never trailed. Led wire-to-wire, clearing spread with 8-point outright victory. Never in doubt.
gameResults.turningPoint: Anthony Black's explosion off bench in 3rd quarter (13 points) broke game open. Magic went on 18-7 run midway through Q3, turning close game into comfortable lead Warriors couldn't overcome.
gameResults.gamePace: Fast-paced, high-scoring game (234 total points). Magic pushed tempo in transition, Warriors tried to match but couldn't keep up defensively. Both teams shot efficiently but Magic's balanced attack won out.
gameResults.teamOffense: Magic shot blistering 52.3% FG with balanced scoring (4 players 15+ points). Warriors relied too heavily on Curry's 34 points - no other Warrior scored 20+. Magic bench outscored Warriors reserves 42-28.

whatWentRight.title: Warriors Road Struggles Continued Exactly as Modeled
whatWentRight.description: Warriors fell to 2-7 on road with 113 points allowed. Road defensive rating woes (117-130 DRTG) played out perfectly. Golden State can't defend away from home.

whatWentRight.title: Franz Wagner and Balanced Attack Overwhelmed Warriors
whatWentRight.description: Franz (18-6-5), Black (21 off bench), Carter (17-12 double-double) created matchup nightmares. Warriors had no answer for Magic's size and depth. Three-headed attack unstoppable.

whatWentRight.title: Magic Home Court Fortress
whatWentRight.description: Orlando improved to 10-2 at Kia Center. Elite home defense (106.3 DRTG) suffocated Warriors down stretch. Home crowd energy fueled Magic dominance.

whatWentRight.title: Line Shopping Paid Off - Got +3.5 vs Consensus +3
whatWentRight.description: Getting extra half-point cushion at +3.5 provided insurance, though Magic won outright by 8 making it irrelevant. Line shopping discipline rewarded.

statisticalContext.vsSeasonAverage: Magic scored 121 (above season average). Franz Wagner's 18 points aligned with elevated role (27.3 PPG without Banchero). Team shot 52.3% FG (elite efficiency).
statisticalContext.vsRecentForm: Warriors extended road losing streak, fell to 2-7 away. Magic improved to 10-2 at home. Both teams following established trends perfectly.
statisticalContext.vsPropLine: Covered +3.5 by 11.5 points with outright 8-point win. Would have covered any spread up to Magic -7.5. Dominant performance exceeded all expectations.
statisticalContext.percentileRanking: Magic's 121 points, 52.3% FG ranked top 20% of performances this season. Warriors allowing 121 on road ranked bottom 15% defensively.

postGameAnalysis.wasNormalVariance: No variance involved - pure skill and proper handicapping. Warriors' road defensive struggles (allowing 121 points) aligned perfectly with 117-130 road DRTG. Magic's balanced attack (Wagner 18, Black 21, Carter 17-12) proved depth advantage. This was textbook execution of road/home split thesis: Warriors can't defend on road, Magic's elite home court advantage creates value. Perfect read.

closingLineValue.verdict: Positive CLV. Line opened Magic +3.5 (-110) and moved to Magic +3.5 (-112) as sharp money hit Magic before tip. We got -110 before it moved to -112, saving 2 cents of juice. The fact that sharp money also hammered Magic validates handicapping. Additionally, getting +3.5 vs consensus +3 at other books provided +0.5 point value.

keyTakeaways: Warriors road defensive struggles (2-7 record, 117-130 DRTG) are exploitable with home underdogs
Magic without Banchero still elite at home with Franz Wagner's elevated play (18-6-5)
Line shopping pays off - got +3.5 vs consensus +3 for extra cushion
Anthony Black's bench explosion (21 points) shows Magic depth advantage over Warriors
Curry's 34 points not enough when no other Warrior steps up (no one else 20+)
Magic bench destroyed Warriors reserves 42-28 - depth differential massive
For quantitative operations: road/home splits remain most reliable NBA handicapping edge
Textbook handicapping - identified Warriors road woes, bet Magic home strength, watched it play out
Magic 10-2 at Kia Center proves home court fortress theory
Covered +3.5 by 11.5 points with outright win - never in doubt after halftime
verdict: Sound process producing expected results with dominant execution. Magic won outright 121-113, covering +3.5 spread by 11.5 points. Warriors' road defensive struggles continued exactly as modeled (fell to 2-7 away, allowed 121 points). Magic's balanced attack (Wagner 18, Black 21, Carter 17-12) overwhelmed Warriors despite Curry's 34 points. Getting +3.5 vs consensus +3 provided extra value through line shopping. This represents proper handicapping: identified clear road/home split advantage, bet it, watched it dominate. Warriors can't defend on road (117-130 DRTG), Magic elite at home (10-2 record, 106.3 DRTG). Would make this bet 100 times out of 100 under identical circumstances. Textbook execution of quantitative edge.
